meanings.definition: To cause or allow something to pass down the throat.
meanings.sent1: She had to swallow the bitter medicine to feel better.
meanings.sent2: He always swallows his food quickly because he is hungry.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to swallow the huge pill, making a funny face.
meanings.sent4: The darkness seemed to swallow the tiny spark of light.
meanings.sent5: The river seemed to swallow everything in its path during the flood.

meanings.definition: To take in and absorb something.
meanings.sent1: The sponge can easily swallow up all the spilled water.
meanings.sent2: Plants need to swallow sunlight to grow and thrive.
meanings.sent3: The book seemed to swallow all her attention, making her forget about time.
meanings.sent4: The desert heat seemed to swallow any moisture in the air.
meanings.sent5: The black hole appeared to swallow entire stars in its gravitational pull.

meanings.sent1: His loud swallow echoed in the quiet room.
meanings.sent2: After the big gulp, she felt the swallow of the drink go down smoothly.
meanings.sent3: The swallow of the huge sandwich made everyone laugh at the table.
meanings.sent4: The swallow of fear was visible in her eyes before the speech.
meanings.sent5: The quick swallow of the bird caught the attention of the onlookers.
